xxl.core.xxlinq
Class AdvPredicate

java.lang.Object
  xxl.core.xxlinq.AdvPredicate
All Implemented Interfaces:
Predicate<Tuple>, CorrTuplesReceiver
public abstract class AdvPredicate
extends java.lang.Object
implements Predicate<Tuple>, CorrTuplesReceiver

A (AdvResultSet)MetaData-aware Predicate on Tuples to be used mainly in JOINS and WHERE-clauses of the AdvTupleCursor.

See Also:

FALSE

public static AdvPredicate FALSE
An AdvPredicate that always returns false, regardless of the input tuples.
Probably mostly useful for testing purposes.

TRUE

public static AdvPredicate TRUE
An AdvPredicate that always returns true, regardless of the input tuples.
Useful to make an equi-join behave like a cross product or for testing purposes.

Method Detail

addContainedColumns

public void addContainedColumns(Column... cols)
Add columns "contained" in this predicate so metadata and correlated tuples can be set for them.
Contained Columns are Columns needed to evaluate this Predicate
Example:
col("al1.nameX").EQ(col("al2.nameY"))
checks whether the columns "al1.nameX" and "al2.nameY", that should be present in your Cursor or the correlated Tuples, are equal.
To map those names to the correct column in the Cursor/Tuple, MetaData and the correlated Tuples are needed. They will be set by where() via setMetaData() and setCorrelatedTuples() of this AdvPredicate and setMetaData() will pass on the metadata to the contained Columns.

Parameters:
cols - Columns to be contained in this Column
See Also:
Column.setCorrelatedTuples(List)

setMetaData

public void setMetaData(AdvResultSetMetaData metadata,
                        java.lang.String newAlias)
Set the AdvResultSetMetaData of the cursor the contained columns (probably) belong to and the new alias of the resulting cursor.
If this is a join Predicate you will have to set the AdvResultSetMetaData of both joined Cursors - see setMetaDatas(AdvResultSetMetaData, AdvResultSetMetaData)

Parameters:
metadata - AdvResultSetMetaData of the cursor, you're calling where/select/group_by on with this column
newAlias - the new alias of the resulting cursor after where/select/group_by (needed especially if this Column contains a given value from val(obj, name)
See Also:
Column.setMetaData(AdvResultSetMetaData, String), setMetaDatas(AdvResultSetMetaData, AdvResultSetMetaData)

setMetaDatas

public void setMetaDatas(AdvResultSetMetaData leftMetaData,
                         AdvResultSetMetaData rightMetaData)
When used as a JOIN-Predicate, set the AdvResultSetMetaDatas of the the left and right Cursors that are joined. It will be passed on to contained Columns, so they can map their given "alias.name" to the appropriate cursor and choose the correct tuple when invoked.

Parameters:
leftMetaData - AdvResultSetMetaData of the left cursor being joined
rightMetaData - AdvResultSetMetaData of the right cursor being joined

getMetaData

protected AdvResultSetMetaData getMetaData()

setCorrelatedTuples

public void setCorrelatedTuples(java.util.List<MapEntry<AdvResultSetMetaData,Tuple>> corrTuples)
Pass a list of tuples along with their metadata from "outer" cursors in case this is a (correlated) subquery. The list has to be sorted from inside to outside (in case of nested subqueries). It will be passed on to the contained Columns.
This is meant to be used with EXISTS, ALL and ANY clauses.

Specified by:
setCorrelatedTuples in interface CorrTuplesReceiver
Parameters:
corrTuples - a List of tuples with their related metadata from "outer" cursors for correlated subqueries
See Also:
AdvTupleCursor#getCorrTuples(), Column.setCorrelatedTuples(List)

getCorrelatedTuples

protected java.util.List<MapEntry<AdvResultSetMetaData,Tuple>> getCorrelatedTuples()

NOT

public static AdvPredicate NOT(AdvPredicate pred)
Creates an AdvPredicate that negates the given AdvPredicate.
Example:
...where( NOT(col("a1.blah").EQ(val("foo"))) )...

Parameters:
pred - the predicate to negate
Returns:
false if pred evaluates to true and vice versa

Parameters:
col - the Column to check for being null
Returns:
true if col is evaluated to null, else false

EXISTS

public static AdvPredicate EXISTS(AdvTupleCursor subquery)
Creates a EXISTS predicate with a (possibly correlated) subquery. If the subquery returns any tuples (or just one), i.e. hasNext() returns true, the predicate returns true, else (there does not exist a single tuple in the subquery) it returns false.
This may not be used as a join Predicate!
Example:
 // some cursors
 AdvTupleCursor cur1 = new AdvTupleCursor(someList, "cur1");
 AdvTupleCursor cur2 = new AdvTupleCursor(someOtherList, "cur2");
 AdvTupleCursor res = cur1.where( 
                EXISTS( cur2.where( col("cur2.a").EQ(col("cur1.x")) ) ) 
        );
This cursor returns all tuples from cur1 with a value in their Column named "x" that is contained in at least one tuple from cur2 at its column named "a".
Note:
  • Because the subquery needs to be re-evaluated for each new "outer" tuple from res' WHERE clause, it can not be cached. Only the first cursor in that query (cur2) will be cached to ensure that it supports reset() (it will be resetted for each "outer" tuple).
  • Subqueries are not really efficient and normally can easily be replaced by a join.

Parameters:
subquery - The subquery evaluated in the EXISTS clause
Returns:
an AdvPredicate implementing an EXISTS-subquery

invoke

public abstract boolean invoke(Tuple argument)
Invokes this Predicate on the given Tuple. The standard use case for this are WHERE-clauses: If the given Predicate evaluates to true, the tuple will be the next tuple returned by next(), if it evaluates to false, the tuple will be discarded. A simple Example: AdvTupleCursor res = cur1.where(col("a").LEQ(val("42")))
LEQ returns an AdvPredicate that compares the given Columns and returns true if the first Column (col("a")) is less or equals the second Column(val("42")), so only Tuples with a value of 42 or smaller in their Column named "a" will be returned by the where-operator.

Specified by:
invoke in interface Predicate<Tuple>
Parameters:
argument - the tuple to be evaluated
Returns:
the result of the predicate as a primitive boolean value.

invoke

public abstract boolean invoke(Tuple leftTuple,
                               Tuple rightTuple)
Invokes this Predicate on the given Tuples. The standard use case for this are JOIN predicates. If the Predicates evaluates to true, the tuples will be concatenated and returned by the join-operator, if it evaluates to false, that combination of tuples will be ignored.
A simple Example: AdvTupleCursor res = cur1.join(cur2, col("cur1.a").EQ(col("cur2.x")));
EQ returns a Predicate that compares the given Columns, in this case column "a" from leftTuple (because leftTuple is from cur1) and column "b" from rightTuple, and if these Columns are equal, leftTuple and rightTuple will be concatenated and returned by the cursor res.

Specified by:
invoke in interface Predicate<Tuple>
Parameters:
leftTuple - tuple of the left cursor being joined (cur1 in example)
rightTuple - tuple of the right cursor being joined (cur2 in example)
Returns:
the result of the predicate as a primitive boolean value.
